div.p: From Joseph Hooker to Julius Haast
MS papers 37, folder 99, Haast family papers, Alexander Turnbull Library, Wellington.

To proof.
I suppose my dear fellow, that every one has some such temporary fit of ambition or vanity, as you say you had, & as has rooted & branched & leafed & flowered in poor Mueller & is now bearing bitter fruit — I doubt if Any man "worth his salt" has been free from it at one time or another, but then with you & the better constituted minds it [is] [...] symptomatic of noble aims [dormant]; it was functional disturbance not morbid disease, as with him. You at least have no cause to think FRS was earned on slender grounds — [...] [...] [...] who came in unanimously in all but as you did, & would have the first time, had not all parties argued that both you & Hector should come in & you must be first — Poor Mueller [has] now a dreadful wail about his pecuniary sacrifices for Science — Why I suppose that had any of us gone in for business we would have made our fortunes, & small credit too — the brains & energy that get us scientific repute were more than fit for that [...]. We all liked science best, & were content to swap worldly goods against mental enjoyment & we have our reward but all this reasoning is thrown away upon poor Mueller.
